ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: That Bs (and even Cs) get degrees.
Critical thinking and calculus.
Calc
I learned how to solve integrals, series, parametric and polar equations.
Through this course, I gained knowledge on how to use and apply the fundamental theorem of calculus, utilizing infinite series, and I gained knowledge on polar and parametric functions.

I learned different methods of integration, how to estimate functions using Taylor series, how to calculate volume of an area that is rotated around a line, and how to take area of polar coordinates. I also learned the importance of doing extra work to succeed in the class and taking advantage of all the resources offered to me.
Basic calculus skills.

While I learned quite a bit about calculus, I learned how to keep up with a fast paced class. When I did not understand something, I knew I had to communicate more with my professor and attend office hours. I learned how to manage my learning and how my success really determined on me asking more questions.
All the basic calc 2 insights I did learn, however it was not taught in the best way.

I learned the basics and foundations of Calculus and delved deep into challenging examples. This course carried me through many topics, which include derivatives, integrals, sequences, series, new applications of integrals, Taylor series, finding volumes, arc length, and areas between curves. I would say this class has a lot of utility for students who want to pursue a course study in econ, math, engineering, etc. Honestly, this class was not taught very well, and I found myself learning the material by simply being taught by the textbook. Each class made me more confused a majority of the time.
I learned calculus concepts and learned the discipline of a Yale Math course.

I learned how to better approach problems regarding polar coordinates, integrals, volumes, series, parametric equation and other important topics of the course. This course allowed me to improve my teamwork skills, especially when it came to study sessions and test prep.
Calculus

I learned a lot of the theory behind different formulas. For example, I feel like the explorations we were required to complete before each class were designed well such that I understood where a lot of concepts came from, as opposed to just accepting and using formulas as given.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Canvas site is well designed. Grade feedback is fast. Small class size is wonderful. There are many facets to the class which makes it easy to learn. 
This class goes at a very fast pace. There is so much content crammed in so tightly. I wish this class were 3 days of the week instead of 2. Many students had already taken AP calc BC which can be frustrating for those of us coming in with no experience with integral calc. I kind of wish that there was a different course offered for students learning this material for the first time since it affects exam curves. 
I am sure I am not the only anxious student who does not like the very high weight timed exams hold on our grade, but since the exams are not unreasonable I cannot fault it too much.

Please standardize this course more. My friends were getting guided notes and very clear breakdowns of the content that would prepare them for the exams. This was not my experience and it seems like a problem that would be so easily solved.
Teaching was kinda tough

Strengths: use of the textbook and was relatively easy to follow, could easily access other resources to learn. 

Weaknesses: I think it was the professors first time teaching, so it was a bit rough. I think with time and practice this would improve.

One of the strengths of this course is that a large number of resources are offered to students who are struggling. Office hours are extremely useful for clarifying any questions that you may have during class or on problem sets, and the peer tutors are extremely helpful as well. One weakness of the course was the rate at which the course was taught. At one point, we were covering content in class that would be on the midterm later that day. Other sections in the course had already covered some of the content we were going over.

I liked the material it covers, and the pace it moves at was challenging. There were plenty of resources available. However, the lectures were boring at best, because most of it was watching our instructor solve examples on the board, and there wasn't any coherent idea of how to apply different strategies we learned. Also, the homework did not give a wide enough selection of material to give us sufficient practice with the concepts. There should have been at least double or triple the amount of homework so we could fully grasp the concepts.

Strengths: The textbook and review sessions
Weaknesses: My teacher
It teaches materials well, no particular strengths and weaknesses.
Strengths are that it is well structured and organized, however weaknesses can be that a lo of the learning depends on the abilities of the professor.

I think the the Professor could have done a better job engaging the students during each class and provided more activities that presented real problems. I felt like I had to do a lot of after class research on the topics in order to fully understand them. I liked that the class gave some insight into the origin of each topic or equation but I wish we had focused more on the modern usage.
Could be improved with pre-lecture introductory videos in addition to the explorations.
I wish that we had a better class culture in terms of students getting to know each other.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is one of those pre-req courses for most people so most have little choice in either taking this or 116. However, I am very close to someone who is taking 116, and based on the curriculums, I think this one is better for students with no calc BC experience.
Like only as a prereq or if youre a very mathy person. Also shop sections - it matters a lot
Yes, if it is required for your major. If this is your first math course at Yale and you have already taken Calc BC, then you should be fine.

I would recommend this course to another student. The knowledge I gained was more than worth enduring some of the minor hardships such as the pace at which the class was taught. I believe the content learned in the class can be useful for most people enrolling in the class.

Take this class only if you are fully prepared for it, not if this is the result you got on the math placement exam and you are going into it blind. You need a strong math background to excel, and if you don't have that you need to do twice the amount of work as the other students. For students like me, with a strong humanities background and a weak math one, you will struggle like I did.
Not unless you have to take it but you probably do.
I would recommend this class to another student if they need it as a prerequisite. Otherwise, I don't see the use in taking it.
Course - yes. Section -no.
If youve already taken BC, its pretty basic. If you havent, they teach you nothing dont take it unless you are willing to learn by yourself from the textbook.
Yes, it gives interesting and applicable calculus topics.
Unless this course was vital for another students learning/major, I do not think I would recommend it. I would recommend courses that I felt would better engage the students.
Yes, the material is applicable to numerous fields of study and career paths.
